awd_titl_txt: Untangling the Energetics and Dynamics of Reactions of Ground State Silylidyne Radicals with Mononuclear Main Group Hydrides
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Ralf I. Kaiser of the University of Hawaii at Manoa is exploring chemical reactions between a simple molecule containing one silicon and one hydrogen atom (SiH, formal name "silylidyne")  with other molecules such as water (H2O), hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and ammonia (NH3).   Similar reactions between simple carbon molecules and H2O, H2S and NH3 are well-studied, but little is known about the corresponding silicon reactions.   The chemistry of carbon and silicon are similar in many ways, even to the point that some scientists have asked the question, "why is life on Earth based on the element carbon, and not silicon?"   Professor Kaiser's research is exploring the differences in chemical reactivity of molecules containing silicon and carbon, and is providing insights into chemical reactions in general.  This research is also broad implications and directly contributes to an ongoing effort by astrochemists and astrobiologists to connect the chemistry of space to the birth of stars, the formation of planets, and the evolution of life. More broadly, this project impacts society through the dissemination of its research results, through outreach activities to researchers, college students, and high school teachers via interdisciplinary symposia, by broadening the participation of underrepresented minorities, and by relaying the project's latest breakthroughs directly to educators enabling them to incorporate research activities into classroom curricula.

By conducting state-of-the-art crossed molecular beam experiments of ground state silylidyne radicals (SiH) with prototype mononuclear main group (IV - VI) hydrides and combining these results with ab initio and quasi-classical trajectory (QCT) calculations in collaboration with Prof. Martin Head-Gordon (UC Berkeley), the proposed investigations explore the hitherto elusive chemical dynamics of silicon-bearing systems and untangle the formation of exotic dinuclear silicon-carrying molecules, of which many have only been predicted to exist theoretically. The project is advancing the fundamental understanding of the chemical bonding of silicon-based molecules, transform the knowledge of the unimolecular decomposition of chemically activated silicon-bearing reactive intermediates and evaluate the processes which control them, establish predictive concepts of non-adiabatic reaction dynamics in silicon-bearing molecular systems, and illuminate the perception of isovalency on the molecular level by comparing the reaction dynamics of the silylidyne radical (SiH) with those of the isovalent methylidyne (CH) systems. Participating graduate and undergraduate students are being trained in cutting-edge laboratory techniques (reactive scattering experiments, ultra-high vacuum setups, laser techniques) along with data analysis and dissemination of their research results in peer-reviewed journals. The PI's group also plans an annual one-week National Summer Teacher Workshop, aimed at teachers from local and mainland high schools, that emphasizes hands-on laboratory activities in astrochemistry and how the results from fundamental research in gas phase chemistry (reaction mechanisms, chemical dynamics) are applied to better understand the chemistry occurring in the solar system (comets, meteorites, planets and moons) and interstellar medium.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Although both silicon (Si) and carbon (C) reside in the same main group XIV of the periodic system of the elements, surprisingly little is known on the gas-phase reaction dynamics and unimolecular decomposition of small, silicon-bearing molecules. Here, we untangled the fundamental reaction pathways of the two simplest silicon-bearing open shell reactants ? atomic silicon (Si) along with the silylidyne radical (SiH) ? with second [methane (CH4), ammonia (NH3), water (H2O)] and third row [silane (SiH4), phosphine (PH3), hydrogen sulfide (H2S)] hydrides exploiting crossed molecular beam experiments and electronic structure calculations. These reactions were documented to proceed without entrance barrier and involved indirect scattering dynamics; isomerization pathways (hydrogen shifts, cyclization, ring opening) and non-adiabatic reaction dynamics drive the overall exoergic reactions and delivered vital knowledge on the chemical bonding of sili?con-bearing reactive intermediates and reaction products in form of bimolecular silicon-bearing molecules of various degree of hydrogenation. Overall, the combined experimental and computational studies afforded persuasive evidence on a rapid and vigorous silicon chemistry in extreme environments such as in cold molecular clouds and circumstellar envelopes of carbon stars eventually providing previously unknown pathways to fundamental molecular building blocks to three classes of nanoparticles in deep space: silicates, sulfides, and carbides.

This project also trained ten scientists in reaction dynamics encompassing underrepresented groups (Female Scientists, Veterans, African American) at the graduate student and postdoctoral level. Our collaborative training involved well-reputed theoreticians (M. Head-Gordon, UC Berkeley; A.H.H. Chang, National Dong Hwa University, Taiwan; R. Sun, University of Hawai?i; A.M. Mebel, Florida International University; B. R. Galvao, Centro Federal de Educacao Tecnol?gica de Minas Gerais, Brazil) and astrochemical modelers (T.J. Millar, University of Belfast, UK) demonstrating our commitment to train scientists capable of assuming leading roles in science in the future.  Besides peer-reviewed publications, the PI organized the ACS Fall Symposium ?Elucidating the Interstellar and Circumstellar Chemistry of Silicon? and co-organized the Pacifichem Symposium ?Misconceptions in Astrochemistry - A Physical Chemists Guide?. These meetings were immensely successful in attracting young and female scientists to the lectures thus providing an overview how basic research in gas-phase reaction dynamics translates into broader impacts such as chemistry of the interstellar medium and in circumstellar enveloped thus bringing us closer to the fundamental processes driving the chemistry of our universe.  

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/07/2023
Modified by: Ralf I Kaiser
